tit.cmt: Tsutaiban→誤訳のためTsukaibanに訂正しました。

sen.j: 使番（つかいばん）とは、江戸幕府の職名。
sen.e: Tsukaiban is a post in the Edo shogunate.
Tsukaiban is a post in the Edo shogunate.
Tsukaiban is a post in the Edo shogunate.

sen.j: 古くは使役（つかいやく）とも称した。
sen.e: In older times, it was also called tsukai-yaku
In older times, it was also called tsukai-yaku.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。
sen.e: In older times, it was also called tsukai-yaku.

sen.j: 若年寄の支配に属し、役料500石・役高は1,000石・布衣格・菊之間南際襖際詰であった。
sen.e: Under the command of the wakadoshiyori, the officer earned executive allowance of 500 koku (rice yield) and salary of 1,000 koku, was of Hoi (noble) rank and was stationed to be at the side of the southern door of the Kiku-no-ma Hall.

Under the command of the wakadoshiyori, the officer earned executive allowance of 500 koku (rice yield) and salary of 1,000 koku, was of Hoi (commoner) rank and was stationed to be at the side of the southern door of the Kiku-no-ma Hall.
sen.cmt: Hoi (noble)→誤訳のためHoi (commoner)に訂正しました。
sen.e: Under the command of the wakadoshiyori, the officer earned executive allowance of 500 koku (rice yield) and salary of 1,000 koku, was of Hoi (commoner) rank and was stationed to be at the side of the southern door of the Kiku-no-ma Hall.

sen.j: その由来は戦国時代 (日本)において、戦場において伝令や監察、敵軍への使者などを務めた役職である。
sen.e: The post originates from the function of the military officer in Japan's Warring Period, who served as messenger and scout in the battlefield and messenger to the enemy army.
The post originates from the function of the military officer in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), who served as messenger and scout in the battlefield and messenger to the enemy army.
sen.cmt: Japan's Warring Period→the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)に訂正しました。（用語統一）
sen.e: The post originates from the function of the military officer in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), who served as messenger and scout in the battlefield and messenger to the enemy army.

sen.j: これがそのまま江戸幕府においても継承された。
sen.e: The post stayed in the Edo shogunate.
The post stayed in the Edo shogunate.
The post stayed in the Edo shogunate.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)3年（1617年）に定制化されたが、皮肉にもその後島原の乱以外に大規模な戦乱は発生せず、目付とともに遠国奉行や代官などの遠方において職務を行う幕府官吏に対する監察業務を担当する事となる。
sen.e: The post was made official in 1617 but, except during the Shimabara Rebellion, never took part in major warfare and became to focus on surveillance of shogunate administrators such as engoku-bugyo and daikan (governors) who executed shogunate policy in remote locations.

The post was made official in 1617, but except during the Shimabara Rebellion, never took part in major warfare and began to focus on surveillance of shogunate administrators such as ongoku-bugyo (the collective name of the magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government in the Edo period) and daikan (governors) who executed shogunate policy in remote locations along with metsuke (inspectors).
sen.cmt: but,→, butに訂正しました。became to→began toに訂正しました。（文法上）engoku-bugyo→ongoku-bugyo (the collective name of the magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government in the Edo period)に訂正しました。（誤訳のため、また説明も補足）「目付とともに」の訳漏れを訂正しました。
sen.e: The post was made official in 1617, but except during the Shimabara Rebellion, never took part in major warfare and began to focus on surveillance of shogunate administrators such as ongoku-bugyo (the collective name of the magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government in the Edo period) and daikan (governors) who executed shogunate policy in remote locations along with metsuke (inspectors).

sen.j: 以後は国目付・諸国巡見使としての派遣、二条城・大坂城・駿府城・甲府城などの幕府役人の監督、江戸市中火災時における大名火消・定火消の監督などを行った。
sen.e: Later, the officer became responsible for service as inspector of foot soldiers, shokoku-junkenshi, supervision of shogunate administrators at Nisho Castle, Osaka Castle, Sunpu Castle, Kofu Castle, etc., as well as supervision of daimyo hikeshi (daimyo's firefighters) and jobikeshi (firefighters under the direct control of the Edo shogunate) in case of fire outbreak in Edo.

Later, the officer became responsible for service as kunimetsuke (inspector of feudal domains), shokoku-junkenshi (envoy responsible for surveillance of the daimyo), supervision of shogunate administrators at Nijo-jo Castle, Osaka-jo Castle, Sunpu-jo Castle, Kofu-jo Castle, etc., as well as supervision of daimyo hikeshi (daimyo's firefighters) and jobikeshi (firefighters under the direct control of the Edo shogunate) in case of fire outbreak in Edo.
sen.cmt: inspector of foot soldiers→誤訳のためkunimetsuke (inspector of feudal domains)に訂正しました。定訳不明です。shokoku-junkenshi→()内の説明を補足しました。Nisho Castle→Nijo-jo Castle、Osaka Castle→Osaka-jo Castle、Sunpu Castle→Sunpu-jo Castle、Kofu Castle→Kofu-jo Castleに訂正しました。
sen.e: Later, the officer became responsible for service as kunimetsuke (inspector of feudal domains), shokoku-junkenshi (envoy responsible for surveillance of the daimyo), supervision of shogunate administrators at Nijo-jo Castle, Osaka-jo Castle, Sunpu-jo Castle, Kofu-jo Castle, etc., as well as supervision of daimyo hikeshi (daimyo's firefighters) and jobikeshi (firefighters under the direct control of the Edo shogunate) in case of fire outbreak in Edo.

sen.j: 定員は元和期には28名を定員とした（25名説もある）が、次第に増員されて文化 (日本)年間には50名前後、幕末に入ると一気に急増して最大で112名に達した。
sen.e: The number of such officers was believed to be 28 (or 25, according to some sources) in the Genna era and was gradually increased to around 50 in the Bunka era, shooting up to 112 in the last years of the Edo Period.

sen.j: そのため、慶応2年（1866年）に定員を半分の56名に削減し、翌年には役料を1,000石以上には金500両、以下にはその半分と改めた。
sen.e: For this reason, the number was halved to 56 in 1866, with executive allowance kept at 500 ryo (gold pieces) for those earning more than 1000 koku and half the amount for lower-rank earners.

For this reason, the number was halved to 56 in 1866, and salary was revised in the following year, with executive allowance kept at 500 ryo (gold pieces) for those earning more than 1000 koku and half the amount for lower-rank earners.
sen.cmt: 「翌年には～改めた」の訳漏れを訂正しました。
sen.e: For this reason, the number was halved to 56 in 1866, and salary was revised in the following year, with executive allowance kept at 500 ryo (gold pieces) for those earning more than 1000 koku and half the amount for lower-rank earners.

sen.j: なお、大奥にはこれとは別個に御台所や大奥の上臈と役人との連絡にあたる「御使番」が設置されている。
sen.e: Separate from this, there was the otsukaiban in O-oku, who served as liaison officer between the Midaidokoro (wife of the Shogun) or other high-ranking woman servants) and the shogunate administrators.

In addition, there was the otsukaiban in O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside), who served as liaison officer between the Midaidokoro (wife of the Shogun) or other high-ranking woman servants and the shogunate administrators.
